qas.question: What is a measure of pesticides determined in EPA studies?

answers.text: material is safe to use and the effectiveness

qas.question: Who is protected by EPA regulations?
Pesticides are inspected often to make sure they meet up to date safety regulations from what period of time.
How often are pesticides produced more recently evaluated for safety?
How could someone learn more about how to safely use and handle an unknow pesticide?
In what year was the EPA established?
How many years did it take to pass the FIFRA act?
What are foods assigned to based on the FQPA act passed in 1984?
What happens to foods in a Toxicity Class after 1984?

plausible_answers.text: to meet the current scientific and regulatory standards

qas.question: Why are foods evaluated after 1984 reassessed?

context: In the United States, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) is responsible for regulating pesticides under the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act (FIFRA) and the Food Quality Protection Act (FQPA). Studies must be conducted to establish the conditions in which the <a0_0>material is safe to use and the effectiveness<a0_0/> against the intended pest(s). The EPA regulates pesticides to ensure that these products do not pose adverse effects to <a1_0>humans or the environment<a1_0/>. Pesticides produced <a2_0>before November <b5_0>1984<b5_0/><a2_0/> <b8_0>continue to be reassessed<b8_0/> in order <b9_0>to meet the current scientific and regulatory standards<b9_0/>. All registered pesticides are reviewed <a3_0>every <b6_0>15<b6_0/> years<a3_0/> to ensure they meet the proper standards. During the registration process, a <a4_0>label<a4_0/> is created. The label contains directions for proper use of the material in addition to safety restrictions. Based on acute toxicity, pesticides are assigned to <b7_0>a Toxicity Class<b7_0/>.
